title: Two-sided Conclusion
question_text:
A group of college students in a psychology class wonders if the order of treatments changes the outcome of a study.
To test this, they ask students in a blind taste test which of two colas they prefer, Pepsi or Coke. In this blind taste test, the first $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Pepsi and then Coke. The next $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Coke and then Pepsi.
Suppose the test statistic is $z = 1.56$ when comparing the proportion of those who preferred Pepsi when tasted first to the proportion who liked Pepsi when tasted second.
On a two-sided test, what is the appropriate conclusion?â€‹

Since
p
>
0.05
, strong evidence exists of no difference between the treatments.

Since
p

0.1
, strong evidence exists of a difference in treatments.

p

0.05
, strong evidence exists of a difference in treatments.

Since
p

0.1
, there is insufficient evidence of a difference in preference based on which order the sodas are given.

Since
p
>
0.1
, strong evidence exists that order does not affect preference.
